name: MedGraphETL
description: An ETL pipeline that extracts medical literature from PubMed and PubMed Central, applies Named Entity Recognition (NER) and Relation Extraction (RE) to identify medical concepts, normalizes entities via UMLS API, and constructs a graph database in Neo4j for knowledge exploration and analysis.

overview.title: Project Overview
overview.content: MedGraphETL is a comprehensive ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) pipeline designed to build medical knowledge graphs from authoritative medical literature. The system processes cancer-related articles from PubMed and PubMed Central, extracts medical entities and their relationships using NLP techniques, normalizes them through UMLS API, and stores the structured knowledge in a Neo4j graph database. The project includes both backend processing capabilities and a frontend interface for interactive exploration of the medical knowledge graph.

features.title: Key Features
items: Configurable ETL pipeline with CLI for extracting medical literature
Named Entity Recognition using ScispaCy (en_ner_bionlp13cg_md model)
Relation Extraction using Spacy Matchers and Dependency Matchers
Entity normalization via UMLS API for standardized medical concepts
MongoDB integration for intermediate article storage
Batch processing with configurable parameters (max-results, batch-size)
Full-text article extraction support from PubMed Central
Neo4j graph database storage with efficient loading strategies
Interactive web-based frontend for graph visualization and exploration
RESTful FastAPI backend for programmatic data access

dataSources.title: Data Sources
items: PubMed API - Medical literature abstracts and metadata
UMLS (Unified Medical Language System) - Medical concept normalization and standardized terminology

backend.database: Neo4j Neo4j (for the graph) | MongoDB  (for abstracts)

requirements.title: System Requirements
items: Python (specific version in .python-version file, <3.13 due to thinc/spaCy dependencies)
PubMed API credentials (optional but recommended for higher rate limits)
UMLS API key (required for entity normalization)
Environment configuration file (.env) with API keys and connection strings
